BATCH CHANGE: primarily orgName and bibCit cleanup
converted textual apostrophes and quotation marks to entity references
BATCH CHANGE: primarily TGENRENAME cleanup, BIBCIT following P moved before P, BIBCITS TAG added
BATCH CHANGE: March 2005 Specifications. Mainly tag/attribute name changes

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Charlotte Brontë, the third daughter in the family, was born in
Thornton
, near
Bradford, in Yorkshire
.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She was baptised on June 29.
71

CB came from an Irish and English background,
Anglican on both sides. Her father's tireless activity as rector in Haworth and surrounding areas made her a member of a prominent and respectable, if financially strapped, family. At least once, however, the Brontës' Irish origins were used to ridicule their brother Branwell.

Despite or perhaps because of his brother's participation in late eighteenth-century nationalist insurrection, her father firmly defended the 1801 Act of Union. He publicly supported Catholic Emancipation in 1829, however, despite his generally Tory politics, and fought for political, social, and sanitary reform.

CB's own political position was complex, though largely Tory and strongly anti-Catholic. Her work is often read as an articulation of the tensions in middle-class Victorian feminism.
4, 157

Maria Branwell was the daughter of a prosperous merchant from Penzance; her parents' deaths left her with a life annuity of ¥50. She was twenty-nine when she met Patrick Brontë, having moved to Yorkshire to assist her uncle with a boarding school at Woodhouse Grove. Little is known of her, but her surviving letters to her future husband suggest a lively, intelligent, and well-educated woman. She married him on 29 December 1812. Several years after their marriage, she wrote a piece on The Advantages of Poverty, in Religious Concerns , which she hoped to publish.
48-9, 51, 52-6, 57, 69

Patrick Brontë was an Irish protestant from a large respectable farming family of limited means. He took to books from an early age, opened a school for the gentry at the age of sixteen, became a gentleman's tutor, and finally saved enough to attend Cambridge at the age of twenty-five.
At Cambridge he adopted the family name of Bronte as a regularization of various spellings which had been employed in Ireland.
2-3
The family Brontë tutored was headed by an evangelical minister, Thomas Tighe, who assisted his entry into the evangelical St John's College at Cambridge as a sizar. He was also assisted financially by Henry Thornton and William Wilberforce. He volunteered for the local militia in preparations to resist the anticipated invasion of Napoleon, drilling under Lord Palmerston in 1804, while earning a first-class Bachelor of Arts in 1806.
6, 11, 9, 12
His eventual position as a clergyman and published author in early nineteenth-century England was, given his background, a considerable accomplishment. Notwithstanding Elizabeth Gaskell's portrait of him in her biography of his daughter as an eccentric, hot-tempered, and difficult recluse, his associates considered him kind and genial.
2-3, 107-8

Patrick Brontë was ordained late in 1807 and held several curacies, mostly in Yorkshire, where he worked with evangelical fervour to serve far-flung communities.
He raised money to distribute Bibles to the poor, and helped in 1813 to found a Church Missionary Association at Bradford, for work in Africa and the East.
60-1
He also preached strongly against the Luddite activity, including riots and assassination, taking place in the north of England. In February 1820 Brontë took up the perpetual curacy of Haworth, which gave him ¥170 per year.
15, 29, 34, 37, 57, 45-7, 80-8

Patrick Brontë had literary aspirations and published several books.
As early as 1810, he had published a poem on didactic subjects, and by 1813 had published two books of like pieces, Cottage Poems and The Rural Minstrel. Another collection of 1815, The Cottage in the Wood, inaugurated the spelling Brontë
69 for the author's name. His anonymous 1818 novella, The Maid of Killarney; or, Albion and Flora, a modern tale . . . , describes Ireland through the eyes of an English hero; it details Irish poverty, disapproves of Catholic Emancipation, and supports legal reform
42, 44, 57, 69
His The Maid of Killarney had a considerable influence on the writings of his children.
76-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Maria Brontë, the eldest of the Brontë children, was baptized.
Elizabeth Brontë, the second of the Brontë children, was born.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Charlotte's birth the next year was soon followed by Branwell's in 1817. Emily's birth came on 30 July 1818, and that of Anne, the youngest, on 17 January 1820.
78, 86

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Patrick Branwell Brontë, the only son of the family, was born: he was known as Branwell.

SHORTPROSE.P: Branwell was an important literary collaborator of his sisters, CB in particular, in their youth.

In early April 1820, the Brontës moved to
Haworth, in the West Riding of Yorkshire
, where their father took up the position of perpetual curate. Despite the depiction of the village as an isolated, primitive place full of uneducated, violent inhabitants (by both CB in her biographical preface to Wuthering Heights and Elizabeth Gaskell in her Life of Charlotte Brontë), it was a busy mill town of about 4,500 people on a textile trade route and was, during the Brontës' time, undergoing rapid growth and change as a result of the industrial revolution.
92

The poor health and high mortality rates in Haworth—on a level comparable with London's worst—were caused by deplorable sanitation and poor water supply.
96, 635

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: The Brontës' mother, Maria Brontë, died at the age of thirty-eight, having fallen ill in January with cancer, probably of the uterus.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Several of the children had scarlet fever during her illness. Maria's death left her stricken husband considerably poorer, since her annuity ceased on her death; he received some additional money through donations and a subscription. Elizabeth Branwell, the sister who had come to help nurse Maria, stayed on to care for the children. This arrangement became permanent.
103, 105
Patrick Brontë offended the family friend Elizabeth Firth by proposing to her only months after his wife's death in an attempt to provide a mother for his children. He also seems to have pursued two other women as potential second wives.
106, 113

Their father regularly dined with his young children, showed considerable care for their development, adjudicated disputes arising from their home theatricals, and often walked with them on the moors.
108-10
Biographer Juliet Barker objects strongly to Gaskell's representation of Patrick Brontë as a domestic hyena, arguing that she used his alleged failure as a parent to excuse the shocking qualities in his daughters' writings.
107-8

The Brontë children were taught when young by their father, who gave them regular oral lessons, by their aunt, who supervised their lessons and work in the house, and by servants who taught them such skills as sewing. The eldest, Maria, read to her siblings from newspapers, which provided lively accounts of issues and events of the day.
110-2

Maria and Elizabeth were sent briefly to Crofton Hall, a school near Wakefield. In July of 1824, they were moved to a newly established school, shortly thereafter followed by Charlotte.
117-8, 128 103
Like them, she had recently had whooping cough and measles.

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB arrived at the strict and parsimonious Clergy Daughters' School in
Cowan Bridge, Tunstall parish
, the original of Lowood School in Jane Eyre.

SHORTPROSE.P:
The fees for the school were ¥14 per year. It was primarily an Evangelical school aimed to assist needy clergymen with the education of their daughters in a plain and useful Education, which may best fit them to return with Respectability and Advantage to their own Homes, or to maintain themselves in the different Stations of Life to which Providence may call them. Its list of eminent patrons included Hannah More and several associates and patrons of Patrick Brontë. CB claimed that her portrait of the school and its personnel was both just and immediately recognizable to those who knew it.
118-21

CB, who had never been away from home, found adjusting to school difficult. She was recognized as clever on entrance, and like her eldest sister was trained for work as a governess. Her sister Emily arrived in November.
129

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Maria Brontë, the original of Helen Burns in Jane Eyre, was removed from the Clergy Daughters' School, seriously ill with consumption. She died at home in early May.
Emily and CB were removed permanently from the Clergy Daughters' School, after their consumptive elder sister Elizabeth had been sent home the previous day.

SHORTPROSE.P: Elizabeth died in mid-June at the age of ten.

The years following Emily's and CB's return to Haworth were marked by extreme poverty and unemployment in the region, as well as trade union agitation and measures against it by employers.
143-4

Their education continued at home from a selection of standard texts including
Oliver Goldsmith's History of England ,
Hannah More's Moral Sketches ,
John Bunyan's Pilgrim's Progress ,
Isaac Watts's Doctrine of the Passions , and
Milton's Paradise Lost , in addition to the limited libraries of their father and their aunt. The Bible and Prayer Book were also used as teaching texts. They studied French, and there is some evidence that all three of Emily, Anne, and Charlotte acquired some familiarity with classical literature, although whether they studied the languages is unclear. They also had, with their brother, drawing and music lessons from about 1829.
166, 145-7

Both Charlotte and Branwell aspired to become artists. She studied drawing seriously, first with a private tutor, later at Roe Head, and after her return independently, by copying romantic illustrations from annuals such as Friendship's Offering and The Keepsake as well as drawing from life.
Branwell, however, unlike his sister, was provided with a prestigious tutor at the exorbitant rate of two guineas per lesson, and intended for further schooling at the Royal Academy and a study tour of Europe.
214, 224, 245
Branwell set up a studio in Bradford for a short time, but gave it up in May of 1839.
213, 302
CB was later, at Roe Head, discouraged from continuing with piano lessons because of her extreme short-sightedness, but Emily and Anne played, and their father bought a piano in 1833 or 1834.

They regularly read Blackwood's Magazine through a friend, and probably frequented a circulating library at nearby
Keighley
. They also had access to lectures at the Keighley Mechanics' Institute, of which their father became a member in 1832, on such subjects as British poetry.
148-9, 212-13

The Brontë children devised private plays in their early years, starting from a group of a dozen wooden soldiers they dubbed the Young Men. The games, which initially involved Charlotte, Branwell, Emily, and Anne, developed over many years into the Glass Town Confederation, loosely modelled on the United Kingdom, with a kingdom for each of the four children. Often based on accounts of historical and political events from newspapers and books, the games gave rise to a body of written juvenilia, more and more elaborate sagas of love, hate, betrayal, war, exploration, and politics. The earlier stages were documented mostly by Charlotte and Branwell, and eventually gave rise to the very different Oriental and imperial Angria. The vividness of this imaginative play is evident in the degree to which the worlds of their creation merge with the real world in Emily's diary. Elements of fantasy played a significant role in the lives of the Brontë children into their mid-twenties.
151-4, 238, 156

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB distinguished herself at Miss Wooler's Roe Head School, on the outskirts of
Mirfield, near Hartshead, Yorkshire
.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She rose to the top of her class by the end of her first six months, and stayed there until her departure, as well as winning prizes in French. There she also met
Mary Taylor and
Ellen Nussey

Taylor and Nussey became lifelong friends and correspondents of CB. She spent short holidays at their homes.
172, 174, 176

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB expressed her satisfaction that the Lords had thrown out the Reform Bill, which she opposed though her father supported it.

Patrick Brontë opened a National Church Sunday School at
Haworth
, to which Emily, and Anne, and CB contributed by teaching.

SHORTPROSE.P:
During this period, she exchanged visits with Ellen Nussey and continued her collaborative writings with Branwell. The siblings attended concerts of the Haworth Philharmonic Society and, from spring of 1834, concerts such as Handel's Messiah on the new church organ.
187, 193, 210

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB reluctantly returned to Miss Wooler's Roe Head School as a teacher.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her salary was largely absorbed by the cost of her sister Emily's school fees and their clothing.
237

Emily left in poor health after only a few months. CB attributed the decline to her sister's powerful yearning for home and the moors. Though she too found life at Roe Head confining, she found some consolation in her vivid imaginings. By August 1836, however, she was complaining in her diary about spending all the best part of my life in this wretched bondage, forcibly suppressing my rage . . . .
254 237, 254

During the following Christmas holidays, the Brontës' servant Tabby Aykroyd fell and shattered her hip; the sisters won a battle with their aunt to keep her at their home and nurse her. She recovered but had to leave her position a few years later.
259

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Anne and CB apparently experienced crises of faith around this time; Anne was also seriously ill.
CB left her position as a teacher at Roe Head, convinced that her life depended on relief of her depressed health and spirits.

SHORTPROSE.P:
By August she returned to Roe Head, owing to family financial pressures, but finally resigned for good at Christmas. Her father's health was visibly deteriorating by this time.
292, 298, 296

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB declined a marriage proposal from the Reverend Henry Nussey, the brother of her friend Ellen.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Nussey's proposal had been very matter-of-fact. She received another proposal later that year from a visiting Irish clergyman who had met her just once. Clearly, despite her unhappiness, she was unwilling to enter into a loveless marriage.
314

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB took a temporary position as a governess not far from Haworth.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She found her duties degrading and felt herself publicly humiliated by her employer. She concluded to Emily, a private governess has no existence, is not considered as a living and rational being.
310 Her friend Mary Taylor decided to emigrate to New Zealand rather than take up such employment.
310

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB gained her first experience of rail travel and a first, inspiring sight of the sea during a holiday at
Bridlington, Yorkshire
, on the east coast, with her friend Ellen Nussey.

CB began working as governess for ¥20 a year at
Upperwood House, near Rawdon
.
The Brontë sisters decided to set up a school of their own.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Their aunt Elizabeth Branwell offered to loan them ¥100 for the purpose, and CB persuaded her to advance some of it to underwrite a period of education in Brussels for herself and Emily.
362

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Emily and CB left for further schooling in
Brussels
, stopping for three days in
London
en route.

SHORTPROSE.P:
They were accompanied by their father and Mary and Joe Taylor. CB insisted on seeing the major buildings and galleries.
377-8

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Emily and CB were pupils at the Catholic Pensionnat Heger in
Brussels (
rue Isabelle
, which is no longer in existence).

SHORTPROSE.P:
The composition instruction of the demanding master of rhetoric, Monsieur
Constantin Heger , had a particularly strong impact on CB's writing. They took lessons in French and German.
384ff, 404

They covered the cost of extending their stay by giving lessons in English and music in exchange for the language lessions they received.
384ff, 404

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Elizabeth Branwell, the aunt who had stepped in after the death of the Brontës' mother, died; Emily and CB returned from Brussels.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Each of the Brontë sisters received a little under ¥300 from their aunt, mostly in the form of investments in the York and North Midland Railway.
409

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
Having mourned her aunt, CB returned to the Pensionnat Heger as a teacher, travelling alone to
Brussels
.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her salary was ¥16 a year. She continued her studies with M. Heger, who insisted that genius requires self-discipline.
417

CB's pedagogical relationship with the married Constantin Heger was most intense, though not necessarily adulterous.
419 She fell in love with him during her first visit, and returned (as she put it) prompted by what then seemed an irresistible impulse.
12 As she became lonelier in Emily's absence, she grew to resent Mme Heger and to depend on M. Heger for a sense of well being. Her great distress during a school holiday led her to make a confession to a Catholic priest, an incident which became the basis for a scene in Villette.
424 After leaving Brussels she dreamed of him, and corresponded with him for more than a year, until he stopped answering her letters.
12

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB returned to
Haworth
from Brussels.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She found her father with failing sight and in uncertain health and delayed her plan to establish a school. Branwell contributed nothing to the family finances. After he gave up his Bradford studio, he worked as a private tutor in the Lake District, where he pursued literary encouragement from local writers. He soon lost his post, possibly as a result of fathering an illegitimate child. Back in Yorkshire, he worked as a clerk for the Leeds and Manchester Railway, but was again dismissed.
432

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB unsuccessfully attempted to establish a boarding school for young ladies at the
Haworth Parsonage
.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She believed that authorship was closed to her and that teaching was her only option, but reported declining a job in Manchester (as principal teacher at the generous rate of ¥100 a year) in order to stay with her father. She was only three years away from publishing Jane Eyre.
I: 358

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Branwell Brontë began a downward spiral of drinking, debts, and dissipation that hastened his death.

SHORTPROSE.P: He despaired of his affair with Mrs Robinson, for whose family he had been tutor and Anne governess. Although persevering in their literary labours and approaches to publishers, his sisters found his decline painful and embarrassing.

Following the publication of Jane Eyre, CB was kept abreast of many recent publications through gift copies of new books from publishers. She kept her identity secret, however, in deference to Emily's wishes.
549

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Branwell Brontë died of tuberculosis.

SHORTPROSE.P:
CB was devastated by the death of her sister Emily from tuberculosis less than three months later, on 19 December 1848.
576

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB reluctantly set out to accompany Anne, whose health was failing rapidly, to
Scarborough
, together with Ellen Nussey.

SHORTPROSE.P:
On 28 May 1849 her last remaining sibling died of tuberculosis. She arranged for her sister's immediate funeral and burial, rather than transporting the body back to Haworth.
594-5 She wrote to her publisher, Papa has now only me—the weakest—puniest—least promising of his children—Consumption has taken the whole five.
595

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Elizabeth Gaskell initiated her friendship with CB by her sympathetic comments about the sickbed scenes in Shirley.

SHORTPROSE.P:
CB saw a resemblance between Emily and both Gaskell and Harriet Martineau, to whom she also had her publishers send a copy of Shirley.
615 392

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB visited
London
, where she met Thackeray and Harriet Martineau, both of whom she admired.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She stayed at the house of handsome, unmarried George Smith, of Smith, Elder, and Co., and his mother. The night before she left, they hosted a dinner for critics, including John Forster and Henry Chorley.
616-17, 621

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB again visited the Smiths in
London
, where she met a number of young female writers, among others Anne Thackeray and Adelaide Procter.

SHORTPROSE.P:
CB also had a confrontation with George Henry Lewes. She attended the House of Commons, the Chapel Royal, where she saw her hero the Duke of Wellington, and a meeting of the Society of Friends. She had her portrait done by society painter George Richmond.
640-4

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB went from London to her friend Ellen Nussey's in
Yorkshire
; from there she went on to
Edinburgh
to join her friends George Smith and his sister Eliza for a couple of days.

CB returned
home
after visiting
London
,
Yorkshire
, and
Edinburgh
.

SHORTPROSE.P:
CB's epistolary relationship with George Smith, in which she often refers to herself by her masculine pseudonym, was playful and teasing. Biographer Juliet Barker suggests that over the London visits and the Scottish trip she fell in love with him. She certainly seems to have taken his lapses in correspondence and the announcement of his marriage several years later rather hard.
623, 648, 703, 744

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB visited her neighbours Sir James and Lady Kay-Shuttleworth in the
Lake District
, where she met Elizabeth Gaskell.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She and Gaskell quickly established an epistolary friendship.
11

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB visited Harriet Martineau at her home
The Knoll
, in the
Lake District
, where she asked her host to mesmerize her.

SHORTPROSE.P:
The visit lasted a week. Martineau feared CB's nerves might not be up to the experiment and ceased as soon as she began to have an effect on her subject.
663-4

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB received her third proposal when James Taylor, the managing clerk of Smith, Elder, and Co., asked her to marry him; she refused.

CB visited
London
, where her relationship with her publisher and friend George Smith turned away from intimacy.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She stayed with Smith and his mother. He was younger than her by eight years, and their correspondence had become increasingly playful on both sides. He has been read as the original for John Bretton in Villette.
675-7

During the visit, she attended a Thackeray lecture, viewed paintings at Somerset House, went to the Great Exhibition several times, and saw the great actress
Rachel perform twice. Great Exhibition

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB visited Elizabeth Gaskell in
Manchester
on her way back to Haworth.

CB returned to
Filey
, near
Scarborough
, to try to improve her health and to visit Anne's grave.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Late in the year she refused a second invitation from Martineau, but she did not accept it, bowing to the view of her father and friends that Martineau's atheism made a friendship between them inappropriate.
709

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Arthur Bell Nicholls asked CB to marry him; she declined, and her father violently opposed the match.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She had originally had little regard for her father's long-time curate, but gradually grew to feel friendly towards him. The strong passion Nicholls evinced following her refusal—he decided to go as a missionary to Australia—and the injustice of her father's treatment of him, won her sympathy.
710-12

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB spent a month in
London
where she visited a range of institutions including prisons, hospitals, financial sights in the City, and the General Post Office.
CB's father suffered a second and quite debilitating stroke.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Arthur Bell Nicholls visited the neighbourhood shortly afterwards, and she began a correspondence with him. They became engaged in March 1854, on the heels of George Smith's marriage, which had taken place the previous month.
299

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: Elizabeth Gaskell visited CB at Haworth for four days.

CB returned Gaskell's visit with a four-day stay in
Manchester
.

CB married curate Arthur Bell Nicholls. They honeymooned in
Wales and his native
Ireland .

SHORTPROSE.P:
At the time of her marriage, CB had money amounting to ¥1,678 9s 9d, most of it from the proceeds of her writing; it was settled on her for her sole use during her marriage.
756

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE: CB was pregnant and became ill.

SHORTPROSE.P:
She made her will a month later, in favour of her husband, instead of her father as stipulated in her marriage settlement.
770

CHRONSTRUCT.CHRONPROSE:
CB, Mrs Arthur Bell Nicholls, died at
Haworth
of a chill, which was called tuberculosis. It is now generally supposed that she died because she was weakened by exceptionally heavy morning sickness in her pregnancy.

SHORTPROSE.P:
Her body was placed in the family vault in
Haworth Church
on April 4. When Gaskell heard of the circumstances of the death, she regretted she had not known; she would have hoped to save CB's life by inducing the birth.
773-4
Health

Numerous friends and acquaintances of CB wrote tributes or obituaries which initiated the legend of the Brontës and Charlotte in particular: Harriet Martineau in the Daily News on April 6; Matthew Arnold in a short poem in Fraser's Magazine in May; Elizabeth Gaskell anonymously in Sharpe's London Magazine in June.

Ironically, this last piece, with a much-reprinted and similarly exaggerated and gossipy account in the Literary Gazette, prompted Ellen Nussey to suggest that Gaskell should write a true account of the life in order to set the rumours to rest. Nicholls agreed and Patrick Brontë wrote Gaskell to suggest an idea which had in fact already occurred to her. The Life of Charlotte Brontë proved scandalous in itself, and had to be altered to avoid a libel suit. It by no means dispelled all the myths, but presented a compelling, controversial, and enduring account of one of the century's most influential women writers.
775, 778-82, 800

WORKSCITED.SOURCE: Unless otherwise noted, all information is from the FC .
Gaskell, Elizabeth. The Life of Charlotte Brontë. 1975.
Gordon, Lyndall. Charlotte Brontë: A Passionate Life. 1994.
